items.title: What the data tell us about the web in 2024
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹672 â€” December 11, 2024 | Read on the web

ğŸ—“ï¸Â The 2024 Web Almanac â€” This comprehensive report on the state of the web returns to wrap up 2024. This edition has 21 chapters (most of which are available now) covering UX, accessibility, publishing, content distribution, and more. All of the metrics shared are based on real world data from over 16 millionÂ websites.

HTTP Archive

Creating a Pure CSS Halftone Effect in 3 Declarations â€” Creating a halftone effect in pure CSS using just a single div, no pseudos and just three properties. Talk aboutÂ efficient (and visually striking,Â too).

Ana Tudor

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines ofÂ Code â€” The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead ofÂ months.

WorkOS sponsor

CSS Wrapped 2024 â€” A fun (pixel-art filled) exploration of the new additions to the web platform in 2024, including cross-document view-transitions, scroll-driven animations, anchor positioning, andÂ more.

Chrome DevRel Team

Solved By Modern CSS: Feature Image â€” Ahmad shares how container queries and CSS :has() can help build a neat featured image component that changes depending on viewport/container size. As ever, great illustrations and code examples to help ourÂ understanding.

Ahmad Shadeed

Court Orders Automattic to Restore WP Engine's Access to WordPress.org
Ivan Mehta

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ¤¯ Tailwind CSS has just surpassed 1 billion downloads.

  • âœ¨ Here's an update on the progress made in 2024 on the Baseline project.

  • ğŸ§­ Here are the release notes for Safari Technology Preview 209. No new additions but plenty of outstanding issues resolved.

  • ğŸŒ Cloudflare's end of year review highlights plenty of interesting tidbits about internet traffic in 2024.

  • ğŸ“„ This site brings together the best examples of one page websites. There's over 8,500 here to go through. Good inspiration!

  • ğŸ§“ğŸ½ Is Googling for 'old people' and what might this mean for web design if so?

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

â–¶Â Â Custom Dropdowns Just Got a Whole Lot Easier (Finally!) â€” A quick look at the upcoming customizable select element that makes it easy to create totally custom dropdown selects with just HTML and CSS, no JS needed. Itâ€™s currently available behind an experimental flag in Chromium browsers, but wider support is expected inÂ 2025.

Wes Bos

'My Issues with Shorthand Properties' â€” A bold claim here, stating that the â€œremoval of CSS shorthand properties would benefit us allâ€. HÃ¥vard adds that writing explicit properties over shorthand is the way to go: â€œClarity trumpsÂ clevernessâ€.

HÃ¥vard Brynjulfsen

Catch Flaky Tests Before They Break Your Build â€” Flaky tests waste time and erode trust. Learn to flag unreliable tests early and keep your CI/CDÂ smooth.

Codecov by Sentry sponsor

What Do the State of CSS and HTML Surveys Tell Us? â€” Rachel (of the Chrome Web Dev relations team) takes an initial look at some of the most interesting findings from these surveys, highlighting the top browser support issues, missing features, andÂ more.

Rachel Andrew

Using Transformers.js for AI in the Browser â€” Transformers.js is a seriously impressive project we link from time to time that lets you run pretrained machine learning models in the browser. Hereâ€™s a practical look at actually playing with it yourself rightÂ now.

Raymond Camden

Mastering SVG Arcs â€” Akshay shares his love of drawing in code, in turn demystifying how to use radii, rotation and arc direction to make intricate SVGÂ designs.

Akshay Gupta

Multi-State Buttons â€” Typically, buttons are either pressed or they arenâ€™t. But as long as you handle it in an accessible way, you can make a group of radio inputs look like a multi-state button with some neat CSS trickery. Preethi shows usÂ how.

Preethi Sam

How to Code a Shader Based Reveal Effect with React Three Fiber and GLSL
Colin Demouge

Understanding the Main Thread in the Browser
Amrik Malhans

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Gradienty: A Suite of CSS Tools & Generators â€” Currently includes 11 different tools including generators for Tailwind gradients, CSS animations, mesh gradients, text gradients, box shadows, andÂ more.

Gradienty

Roquefort - WebGPU Fluid Simulator â€” A browser-based 3D simulator that uses WebGPU compute shaders. You can edit the scene, speed, along with variousÂ effects.

Jerry Ylilammi

InclusiveColors: A Color Palette Creator for WCAG-CompliantÂ Colors â€” Offers features like precise control of every shade/tint thatâ€™s generated, live contrast checking as you edit, and ability to export to CSS, Tailwind, Adobe products, andÂ more.

Sean Wilson

Codate: Easily Create Custom Date Formats in Any Programming Language â€” A neat little resource to get a code snippet for common date formats â€“ hyphenated, slashed, dotted, standard with commas, etc. Supports 11 languages including JS, Go, Python, Java, PHP, andÂ more.

Badreddine Ibril

PicLooks: Authentic Looking AI-Generated Profile Photos â€” An alternative to using stock photos, these do have a more realistic look than some other AI-generated photos, and theyâ€™re free to use commercially withoutÂ attribution.

PicLooks

VTracer: An Online Tool to Convert Raster Images Into Vector Graphics
Vision Cortex

ğŸ•°ï¸ ICYMI (Older links, still worth checking out)

  • Alex Chan shows us a neat way to create static sites for browsing local files on your machine.

  • Mark Anthony Cianfrani poses a question on the design considerations around letter-spacing: "Use it well. Or donâ€™t."

  • Terence Eden shared a neat trick for showing an external site's favicon when you hover over a link.

Ipx.

items.title: A layered approach to speculation rules
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹671 â€” December 4, 2024 | Read on the web
ğŸ„ğŸ—“ï¸ Frontend Advent Calendars

It's that time of year! Developers a-plenty are penning lots of webdev-related articles as part of Christmas content advent calendars. We'll be featuring many of them here over the coming week's but for those of you seeking daily drops of developer-focused reads, here's where to find them:

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ The HTMHell Advent Calendar, helmed by Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡, once again returns for 2024 bringing together a daily article focusing on HTML, along with related security, assessibility, UX topics and more.

  • ğŸ“‹ The CSS Advent Calendar is a rather traditional looking calendar, complete with festive doors. Behind each one you'll find a brief snippet on a certain CSS feature, along with links out to learn more.

  • ğŸï¸ The annual Web Performance Calendar is a great returning resource for numerous articles on measuring, monitoring and optimizing all things web performance. Speed geeks, this one is for you.

There's plenty of other themed calendars across a variety of disciplines, including of course the puzzling Advent of Code. If you're after more like this Adrian Roselli has a great round-up.

Build with Gemini, Our Largest and Most Capable AI Model â€” Use the Google AI JavaScript SDK to make your first generative AI call using the Gemini API in your client-side web application. Learn everything you need to know at your own pace with Google AIÂ Studio.

Google Gemini sponsor

A Layered Approach to Speculation Rules â€” Harry has been experimenting with the Speculation Rules API, developing something of a multi-tiered approach to really maximizing the benefit of the two speculative loading types (prefetch and prerender).

Harry Roberts

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸª Version 5.0 of web framework Astro has landed, adding Astro Content Layer â€”Â a new flexible way to manage content.

  • ğŸ¨ Adam Wathan and Sam Selikoff â–¶ï¸Â explore the new Tailwind CSS v4.0 beta in this hour-plus long video.

  • ğŸ„ There's a new browser in town from start-up Deta, it's called Surf (great name) and has a chatbot baked in.

  • ğŸ Chicago Kare is a lovely, faithful reproduction of the bitmap Chicago typeface created by designer Susan Kare for Apple back in 1984.

  • ğŸš« This site outlines ten solid reasons why you shouldn't mess with scrolling.

  • ğŸ–¥ï¸ Those of you of a certain pedigree may remember 2Advanced, an early 2000s site with an inspiring, era-defining look.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Dataviz Accessibility Principles, Demonstrated by 2024 Presidential Election Dashboards â€” Sarah has tested the accessibility of various 2024 U.S. Presidential Election data visualizations from various news orgs, looking at the charts and data on show andÂ highlighting the numerous issues. A deep dive with some food for thought on accessible ways to display more complexÂ information.

Sarah Fossheim

Flex Your Product Muscle with Product for Engineers â€” Get curated advice on building great products, lessons from building PostHog, and the strategies of topÂ startups.

PostHog sponsor

The Lowdown on Dropdowns in HTML & CSS â€” If youâ€™re trying to reveal content from user interaction David proclaims that â€œyou should read thisâ€, encouraging us to put down that JavaScript and check out new and upcoming HTML/CSS features to help us do theÂ job.

David Darnes

Frosted Glass from Games to the Web â€” A UI games developer (who worked on the Forza series) shares the process of translating in-game â€˜frosted acrylicâ€™ design elements to HTML. The end result is nice! backdrop-filter does the heavy liftingÂ here.

Tyler Wolf Leonhardt

Creating Effective Multi-Step Forms â€” Looks at the design considerations for good-form experiences, beyond just validation â€”Â specifically on forms that involve navigation betweenÂ sections.

Amejimaobari Ollornwi

Starting Off Right: Where Autofocus Shines â€” On the value of autofocus for enhancing the user experience, particularly on form-heavy single purposeÂ pages.

Kilian Valkhof

A Link on a Logo in the Header: What Should the alt Text Be?
Rian Rietveld

Why We Switched to Astro (And Why It Might Interest You)
Stefano Verna

Avoid Hotlinking Images with Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy
Sjoerd Langkemper

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Tailwind Colors: All The Tailwind CSS Colors in a 'Cheatsheet' â€” You can click to copy any color and choose the desired format, which includes the new OKLCH format that gets transpiled to a more common format with Tailwind versionÂ 4.

tailscan

Kinesis.js: A Library to Easily Create Complex Interactive Animations â€” The home page includes some advanced examples of whatâ€™s possible, which includes the ability to animate elements in response to mouse movement, scroll events, and even audio frequencyÂ data. GitHub repo.

Amine Bouyarmane

Build Fully Functional Apps in Minutes, Not Months â€” Create, run, edit, and deploy full-stack web apps withÂ Bolt.

StackBlitz sponsor

uifonts.app: Test and Preview Fonts in Real Time â€” The fonts, sourced from Google Fonts, are displayed on real UI elements on the page. You can select a primary and secondary font or hit the â€˜randomâ€™ button to preview random fontÂ pairings.

uifontsâ€¤app

Spark UI: A Library of Animated Components Built with Vue, TypeScript, Tailwind, and Vueuse Motion â€” See some demosÂ here.

Selemon Brahanu

ğŸ“° Classifieds

ğŸ¹ STRICH: Add blazing fast and reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning to your web apps. Free demo app and 30-day trialÂ available.

ğŸ’› JavaScript Weekly is our email digest on all things JavaScript. We send a round-up of the latest news, tutorials, and tools every Thursday.

Markwhen: A Text-to-Timeline Tool That Converts Markdown-ish Text to a Cascading Timeline â€” This is beautifully presented.
Markwhen

Awesome Docs Gallery: A Crowdsourced, Open-Source Gallery for High-Quality DevÂ Docs â€” A lot of inspiration here.
hasnode

Ipx.

The Lowdown on Dropdowns in HTML & CSS â€” If youâ€™re trying to reveal content from user interaction David proclaims that â€œyou should read thisâ€, encouraging us to put down that JavaScript and check out new and upcoming HTML/CSS features to help us do theÂ job.

A Link on a Logo in the Header: What Should the alt Text Be?

Tailwind Colors: All The Tailwind CSS Colors in a 'Cheatsheet' â€” You can click to copy any color and choose the desired format, which includes the new OKLCH format that gets transpiled to a more common format with Tailwind versionÂ 4.

items.title: Where to draw the line with browser support
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹670 â€” November 27, 2024 | Read on the web

A Framework for Evaluating Browser Support â€” If you find yourself trying to figure out where to draw the line when it comes to browser support, Josh has some advice, sharing the deciding factors he uses when it comes to CSS features. He notes that although this post focuses on CSS, the framework is applicable to modern JavaScript and HTML featuresÂ too.

Josh W. Comeau

Tailwind CSS v4.0 Now in Beta â€” The long awaited beta for version 4 of the popular Tailwind CSS styling framework is out, with a new engine resulting in 5x faster full builds, a unified toolchain, CSS-first configuration (yes, you can say goodbye to noodling with tailwind.config.js!) and more. All the information you need is in the docsÂ here.

Adam Wathan

Master Performance and Speed Up Your Site â€” This detailed video course shares the fundamentals of web performance, covering key Core Web Vitals metrics such as Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS), and Interaction to Next Paint (INP). You'll learn how to best use Lighthouse, WebPageTest and other tools in order to make your siteÂ lightning.

Frontend Masters sponsor

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • âš™ï¸ The Chrome team gives an update on work being done on WebGPU.

  • ğŸ§‘â€âš–ï¸ WP Engine has updated its ongoing lawsuit against Automattic and Matt Mullenweg. The conflict rumblesÂ on..

  • â„¢ï¸ Deno is stepping up its efforts to have the 'JavaScriptâ„¢ï¸' trademark cancelled, filing a petition with the US Patent and Trademark Office.

  • ğŸŸª You may recall that CSS has a new logo â€” Kilian has created an outline / icon version of it, should you needÂ one.

  • ğŸ”¥ Firefox 133 is out and notably supports keepalive in the Fetch API meaning requests can continue to run even after the page is unloaded, such as during page navigation orÂ closing.

  • ğŸ‘ Did you know about the Device Posture API? Worth knowing about for our foldable future!

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Make Creative Borders with background-clip: border-area â€” Safari is first out of the gate with support for background-clip: border-area, available now in Safari Technology Preview and in Safari 18.2 beta. It lets you fill a border with a background image or gradient. This article explains how it works, and shows up the possibilities in sevenÂ demos.

Jen Simmons

ğŸ“ˆÂ Designing (and Evolving) a New Web Performance Score â€” Harry has been working on a way to compare performance between sites, resulting in a new metric dubbed â€˜CrRRUX â€˜(Chrome Relatively-Ranked User Experience). It aims to simplify competitor analysis into a single number, reflecting real user experiences across a given a cohort of sites. A clear indicator of performance in the context of yourÂ peers.

Harry Roberts

Create Printable Surveys and Forms in No Time â€” Need to generate custom PDF forms? With SurveyJS, you can build and export fillable or read-only forms, even withÂ responses!

SurveyJS sponsor

â–¶Â Â How Browsers Really Load Web Pages â€” A deep dive into how browsers decide when to load a specific resource, and all the ways in which you can influence them to modify theirÂ behaviour.

Robin Marx

The CSS Reset Contradiction â€” Makes the case that resets have become a commodity, resulting in an assumption that thereâ€™s a general need for them, which in turn nibbles â€œat the craft of frontendÂ developmentâ€.

Jens Oliver Meiert

ğŸ•¹ï¸Â Netlify Celebrates 5 Million Developers â€” Netlify is now used by over five million developers â€”Â and theyâ€™ve marked the occasion with a Marble Madness style browserÂ experience/game.
Netlify

â€˜We Were Wrongâ€™: An Oral History of WIREDâ€™s Original Website
Virginia Heffernan

What We Learned Migrating from Webpack to Vite
Roman Zaynetdinov

ğŸ¦‹Â Using Bluesky Posts as Blog Comments
Emily Liu

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Vite 6.0 Released â€” The popular build tool has rapidly found itself at the heart of the frontend ecosystem with its combo of speed, simplicity and extensibility. v6 doubles down on these and has a variety ofÂ enhancements.

Vite

ğŸ“ŠÂ Tremor: React Components for Building Dashboards â€” Built with React, Tailwind CSS, and Radix UI, you can use Tremor by either copy and pasting the components or via their npm package. You get all the typical dashboard UI elements like charts, progress indicators, activity trackers, accordions, tables, etc.

Tremor Labs

AuthKit: The Worldâ€™s Best Login Box â€” Powered by WorkOSÂ &Â Radix â€” AuthKit is a complete solution for authentication, authorization, and user management. Itâ€™s free up to 1 million MAUs and comes standard with RBAC, bot protection, MFA, andÂ more.

AuthKit sponsor

SVG Spinners: 100+ Open Source SVG Loading Spinners â€” You can view them all in action here. Theyâ€™re built with CSS and SMIL, are easy to customize using currentColor, and you can include them as inline SVGs or downloadÂ directly.

Shubham Jain

HTMLrev: A Categorized Directory of Frontend Templates â€” Weâ€™ve featured this before, but itâ€™s now home to over 1,500 templates. The site itself doesnâ€™t hold any templates, but links to third party resources, and lets you filter down to what youâ€™re lookingÂ for.

HTMLrev

Diff Text: A Simple Online Diff Checker Tool â€” Lets you compare by words, characters, or lines and you can toggle show all lines or only changedÂ lines.

Spencer Smith

Spoiled: A Realistic 'Spoiler' Component for React â€” The homepage is a live demo. A neat way to keep things hidden until a user wants to see them. Powered by the CSS Painting API with a static image fallback. GitHubÂ repo.

Alexey Taktarov

ğŸ“ŠÂ One Dollar Stats: Web Analytics Alternative â€” An interesting idea from the folks behind Drizzle ORM.
Drizzle Team

Ipx.
items.contentSnippet:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus


            
#â€‹670 â€” November 27, 2024 | Read on the web

          
        



  





  
  
A Framework for Evaluating Browser Support â€” If you find yourself trying to figure out where to draw the line when it comes to browser support, Josh has some advice, sharing the deciding factors he uses when it comes to CSS features. He notes that although this post focuses on CSS, the framework is applicable to modern JavaScript and HTML featuresÂ too.
Josh W. Comeau 


  
  
Tailwind CSS v4.0 Now in Beta â€” The long awaited beta for version 4 of the popular Tailwind CSS styling framework is out, with a new engine resulting in 5x faster full builds, a unified toolchain, CSS-first configuration (yes, you can say goodbye to noodling with tailwind.config.js!) and more. All the information you need is in the docsÂ here.
Adam Wathan 


  
  
Master Performance and Speed Up Your Site â€” This detailed video course shares the fundamentals of web performance, covering key Core Web Vitals metrics such as Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS), and Interaction to Next Paint (INP). You'll learn how to best use Lighthouse, WebPageTest and other tools in order to make your siteÂ lightning.
Frontend Masters sponsor







âš¡ï¸ Quick Links
âš™ï¸ The Chrome team gives an update on work being done on WebGPU.
ğŸ§‘â€âš–ï¸ WP Engine has updated its ongoing lawsuit against Automattic and Matt Mullenweg. The conflict rumblesÂ on..
â„¢ï¸ Deno is stepping up its efforts to have the 'JavaScriptâ„¢ï¸' trademark cancelled, filing a petition with the US Patent and Trademark Office.
ğŸŸª You may recall that CSS has a new logo â€” Kilian has created an outline / icon version of it, should you needÂ one.
ğŸ”¥ Firefox 133 is out and notably supports keepalive in the Fetch API meaning requests can continue to run even after the page is unloaded, such as during page navigation orÂ closing.
ğŸ‘ Did you know about the Device Posture API? Worth knowing about for our foldable future!










ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion




  





  
  
Make Creative Borders with background-clip: border-area â€” Safari is first out of the gate with support for background-clip: border-area, available now in Safari Technology Preview and in Safari 18.2 beta. It lets you fill a border with a background image or gradient. This article explains how it works, and shows up the possibilities in sevenÂ demos.
Jen Simmons 


  
  
ğŸ“ˆÂ Designing (and Evolving) a New Web Performance Score â€” Harry has been working on a way to compare performance between sites, resulting in a new metric dubbed â€˜CrRRUX â€˜(Chrome Relatively-Ranked User Experience). It aims to simplify competitor analysis into a single number, reflecting real user experiences across a given a cohort of sites. A clear indicator of performance in the context of yourÂ peers.
Harry Roberts 


  
  
Create Printable Surveys and Forms in No Time â€” Need to generate custom PDF forms? With SurveyJS, you can build and export fillable or read-only forms, even withÂ responses!
SurveyJS sponsor


  
  
â–¶Â Â How Browsers Really Load Web Pages â€” A deep dive into how browsers decide when to load a specific resource, and all the ways in which you can influence them to modify theirÂ behaviour.
Robin Marx 


  
  
The CSS Reset Contradiction â€” Makes the case that resets have become a commodity, resulting in an assumption that thereâ€™s a general need for them, which in turn nibbles â€œat the craft of frontendÂ developmentâ€.
Jens Oliver Meiert 


  
ğŸ•¹ï¸Â Netlify Celebrates 5 Million Developers â€” Netlify is now used by over five million developers â€”Â and theyâ€™ve marked the occasion with a Marble Madness style browserÂ experience/game.
  
Netlify 
  


  
â€˜We Were Wrongâ€™: An Oral History of WIREDâ€™s Original Website
  
Virginia Heffernan 
  


  
What We Learned Migrating from Webpack to Vite
  
Roman Zaynetdinov 
  


  
ğŸ¦‹Â Using Bluesky Posts as Blog Comments
  
Emily Liu 
  


ğŸ”§  Code, Tools & Resources





  
  
Vite 6.0 Released â€” The popular build tool has rapidly found itself at the heart of the frontend ecosystem with its combo of speed, simplicity and extensibility. v6 doubles down on these and has a variety ofÂ enhancements.
Vite 


  
  
ğŸ“ŠÂ Tremor: React Components for Building Dashboards â€” Built with React, Tailwind CSS, and Radix UI, you can use Tremor by either copy and pasting the components or via their npm package. You get all the typical dashboard UI elements like charts, progress indicators, activity trackers, accordions, tables, etc.
Tremor Labs 


  
  
AuthKit: The Worldâ€™s Best Login Box â€” Powered by WorkOSÂ &Â Radix â€” AuthKit is a complete solution for authentication, authorization, and user management. Itâ€™s free up to 1 million MAUs and comes standard with RBAC, bot protection, MFA, andÂ more.
AuthKit sponsor


  
  
SVG Spinners: 100+ Open Source SVG Loading Spinners â€” You can view them all in action here. Theyâ€™re built with CSS and SMIL, are easy to customize using currentColor, and you can include them as inline SVGs or downloadÂ directly.
Shubham Jain 


  
  
HTMLrev: A Categorized Directory of Frontend Templates â€” Weâ€™ve featured this before, but itâ€™s now home to over 1,500 templates. The site itself doesnâ€™t hold any templates, but links to third party resources, and lets you filter down to what youâ€™re lookingÂ for.
HTMLrev 


  
  
Diff Text: A Simple Online Diff Checker Tool â€” Lets you compare by words, characters, or lines and you can toggle show all lines or only changedÂ lines.
Spencer Smith 





  





  
  
Spoiled: A Realistic 'Spoiler' Component for React â€” The homepage is a live demo. A neat way to keep things hidden until a user wants to see them. Powered by the CSS Painting API with a static image fallback. GitHubÂ repo.
Alexey Taktarov 


  
ğŸ“ŠÂ One Dollar Stats: Web Analytics Alternative â€” An interesting idea from the folks behind Drizzle ORM.
  
Drizzle Team

items.title: Might Google be forced to sell Chrome?
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹669 â€” November 20, 2024 | Read on the web

How overflow: clip Works in CSS â€” This is a solid look at using the well-supported clip value alongside the overflow CSS property â€” with some good example use cases, particularly around artÂ direction.

Ahmad Shadeed

The State of HTML 2024 Results â€” The results from this yearâ€™s State of HTML survey dropped late last week, and Patrick Brosset (of the Edge team) sums up where things stand in his conclusion:

ğŸ’¬ â€œ..itâ€™s heartwarming that most respondents agree that, overall, interoperability is now much less of an issue than it used to be, with clear improvements being felt in recent years. And, with the increasing number of capabilities weâ€™re getting, building performant, accessible, and interactive HTML-first UIs is becoming easier all the time, making it possible to reduce JavaScript usage to where it truly matters, and letting web servers and browsers communicate how they were meant to: withÂ HTML!â€
â€”Â Patrick Brosset

Build Fully Functional Applications in Minutes, Not Months â€” Create, run, edit, and deploy full-stack web apps withÂ Bolt.

StackBlitz sponsor

Meet Angular v19 â€” The latest version of this popular web app framework is here â€” to mark the release â–¶ï¸Â hereâ€™s a video running through what new features you canÂ expect.

Minko Gechev

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ¤¯ This feels like a big swing that might not amount to much when all is said and done, but the US Justice Department, as part of its search monopoly efforts, wants Google to sell Chrome.

  • âœ¨ Talking of Chrome, version 132 is now in beta with several CSS and Web APIÂ enhancements.

  • ğŸ—³ï¸ The latest State of JS survey is now open and seeking responses.

  • ğŸ“– Tim Brown's 'Flexible Typesetting' ebook is now free to download (if you share your emailÂ address).

  • ğŸ¦Š I missed this a few weeks ago, but Firefox is celebrating 20 years in the browser game.

  • ğŸ¦‹ ICYMI: If you're not on Bluesky yet, here's a starter pack full of friendly frontend folks to help get you started.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Importing a Frontend JavaScript Library Without a Build System â€” Julia explores how to import a JS library when taking a no-build-systemÂ approach.

Julia Evans

alt Text: Donâ€™t Just Describe Images â€” Advice for writing alt text that communicates an imageâ€™s purpose without repeating page content â€” chiefly focus on meaning rather than visualÂ description.

Emma Cionca & Tanner Kohler

Pinpoint Flaky and Failing Tests with Codecov Test Analytics â€” Stop digging through logs and re-running your CI. See why tests are failing and which are flaky, right in yourÂ PR.

Codecov sponsor

Creating an ASCII Shader Using OGL â€” This is an incredibly cool effect, not to mention great tutorial on getting started with shaders and using OGL, a minimal WebGL library thatâ€™s a lot lighter than Three.js.

Andrico Karoulla

â–¶Â Â Nerd Show and Tell: Meet Zach Leatherman â€” Zach talks about the â€œrollercoaster ride of building Eleventyâ€, why owning your corner of the internet is more important than ever, and how platforms like Eleventy could be â€œthe ticket to a new wave of webÂ independenceâ€.

Podcast Awesome podcast

When's the Right Time to Share Our Excitement About New Web Features?
Rachel Andrew

Creating 'No Fuss' Light/Dark Modes â€” Keeping it simple.
Chris Coyier

ğŸ“ŠÂ Adding Interactive Charts to Astro Sites
Pavlin BG

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

SVG to Font 6.1: Read SVG Icons and Output a Font File â€” Both a CLI tool and Node.js library that can read in SVG documents and output WOFF2, WOFF, EOT, TTF and SVG fonts. Useful for generating a Web font from a set of icons, say, as in thisÂ demo.

Kenny Something

lite-youtube Web Component v1.6 Released â€” The latest version of this web component that quickly renders YouTube embeds adds auto-pausing, custom CSS properties, named slot thumbnails, andÂ more.

Justin Ribeiro

Troubleshoot Frontend Issues with Digital Experience Monitoring â€” Learn how Datadog provides a single source of truth for frontend monitoring so teams can troubleshoot issuesÂ faster.

Datadog sponsor

SmarkForm: A Library for Creating Markup-Driven and Extendable Forms in Web Apps â€” This allows you to add advanced features to forms, like JSON import/export, hotkeys, along with other interactive enhancements. Try some examples here.

Joan Miquel Torres

Coding Font: A 'Game' to Find Your New Favorite Code Font â€” This is a fun idea. It throws over 25 popular developer-oriented fonts into a â€˜tournamentâ€™ and you then pick your favorites until youâ€™re left with a winner. (It was Cousine forÂ me.)

Typogram

Monicon: A Universal Icon Library for Any JavaScript Framework â€” The project itself is not new, but provides quick access to 200,000+ icons from popular sets and works with most frameworks and buildÂ tools.

Oktay Åenkan

ğŸ“° Classifieds

Introducing @clerk/nextjs v6, with support for Next.js 15. Learn about v6 updates and upgrade using ourÂ guide.

ğŸ¹ STRICH: Add blazing fast and reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning to your web apps. Free demo app and 30-day trialÂ available.

Ipx.

title: Frontend Focus
description: A onceâ€“weekly roundup of the best front-end news, articles and tutorials. HTML, CSS, WebGL, Canvas, browser tech, and more.
